## The many meanings of Romanness

<div class="leftcolumn">

- Not a barbarian
- Citizen of *res publica Romanorum*
- Loyalty to the Emperor
- Legal rights/status
    - Peasantry  >> *Rhomanoi* in c10 Dalmatia
    - Lawfulness >> People of Law >> Old Testament parallels >> Chosen people
- Language (Latin, later Greek)
    - Further complication: Greek = Hellene = 'pagan'

</div>

<div class="rightcolumn">

- Christian
- Elite paideia
- Patterns fostered by the built environment
- Geography / place of origin
    - *urbs Roma*
    - *Rhomania* >> Romagna / Lombardy

</div>

## The trial of Maximus the Confessor in 653

[Maximus stood] in the middle of the officials, who were seated, and the sakellarios said to him with great anger and frenzy: ‘Are you a Christian [Χριστιανὸς εἶ]?’

And [Maximus] said: ‘By the grace of Christ, God of all, I am a Christian.’

And the sakellarios said: ‘That’s not true.’

The servant of God answered: ‘You say I’m not, but God says that I am, and will remain a Christian.’

‘And how,’ he said, ‘if you are a Christian, can you hate the emperor?’

*Relatio Motionis*, §1.8-16, transl. Allen and Neal (2002), 49.
